prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context
Policy Reasons for Protection of Confidential Information

head.headtext: Legal Protection of the Exclusive Use and Control of Ideas

para.paratext: When there was no commerce in books or inventions, there was no suggestion of copyright or patent. This changed when art and invention became commercialized, and sales were made on a large scale. For books and pictures, the critical invention that brought about the change was the printing press.

Some argue that the only appropriate way to recognize and protect the economic interest and the concomitant rights of inventors or those who own an invention is to grant legal rights. Because ideas have commercial value, it seems right and moral to give the person who thinks them up the control and exclusivity which is fundamental to real property.[1]

The law also supports standards of good faith and fair dealing because such standards are desirable in themselves and because they will promote long-run industrial and commercial efficiency. In Canada, before section 7(e) of the Trade Marks Act[2] was declared unconstitutional,[3] federal courts based their intervention in cases of confidential business information on this section, which prohibited acts and business practices “contrary to honest industrial or commercial usage in Canada”. The principle of upholding honest commercial practices was upheld by La Forest J. for the majority of the Supreme Court of Canada in the LAC Minerals case:

[The essence of the protection of confidences] is its utility in the promotion and preservation of desired social behaviour and institutions … In the modern world the exchange of confidential information is both necessary and expected … The institution of bargaining in good faith is one that is worthy of legal protection in those circumstances where that protection accords with the expectations of the parties.[4]

La Forest J. endorsed the proposition that the law should uphold such standards not only because they are desirable in themselves but also because they promote long-term industrial and commercial efficiency.

An action for breach of confidence consists of two distinct aspects: the nature of the information protected and the nature of the relationship in which the information is divulged. It has been argued that confidence is often linked with privacy and that to deny protection would run counter to the concept of privacy rights. Privacy is the “claim of individuals, groups or institutions to determine for themselves when, how, and to what extent information about them is communicated to others”.[5]

The common law does not recognize a right to privacy, so any protection must come from legislation. The federal Privacy Act[6] provides individuals with a right of access to personal information about themselves and the right to have it corrected. It also serves to prevent others from having access to their personal information which is under the control of federal government institutions. Under s. 184[7] of the Criminal Code,[8] it is an offence for any person to wilfully intercept a private communication by electromagnetic, acoustic, mechanical or other device without the consent of at least one communicating party or without judicial authorization. Section 193[9] of the Criminal Code makes it a crime to disclose the contents of or the existence of any private communication without the consent of at least one communicating party. Further, privileged communications cannot be compelled and are not admissible in a court of law.[10]
However, Glasbeek argues that:

… very little of the case law relating to the action of breach of confidence which protects information does so for the purpose of providing safeguards for knowledge, traits and attributes which make up an individual's personality … it is a secondary objective which, in turn, is sought because the courts are interested in bolstering certain relationships rather than protecting privacy.[11]

This is the historical basis of the French legislation which accords intellectual property the same status as tangible property: M. Bourgeois, “Protecting Business Confidences: A Comparative Study of Quebec and French Law” (1987-88), 3 I.P.J. 259 at p. 286.
